text:
DMS
Data at rest is stored and is usually protected by a firewall or anti-virus software.
Though these methods of protection for data at rest are good, complete safety requires adding an additional layer of defense. This is where encryption at rest comes to play.
I want to save the encryption/decryption key to memory.
So if someone gets the complete server in his hand, he can not access the data without knowing the password.

elements.text:
DMS
Data at rest is stored and is usually protected by a firewall or anti-virus software.
Though these methods of protection for data at rest are good, complete safety requires adding an additional layer of defense. This is where encryption at rest comes to play.
I want to save the encryption/decryption key to memory.
So if someone gets the complete server in his hand, he can not access the data without knowing the password.

text: The main web attack is cross-site scripting, for which I wrote up a full post in detail. HTTPS does nothing to mitigate it.

text: Then there's SQL/code injection: even if you're only using DBF's you should make sure no text entered by a user can be executed as harbour code

text: Those are the two main classes of attacks. They're not the only ones, by far, but if you take steps to mitigate them, and use HTTPS and encryption at rest, you should be fairly well protected

elements.text: Those are the two main classes of attacks. They're not the only ones, by far, but if you take steps to mitigate them, and use HTTPS and encryption at rest, you should be fairly well protected
